t: Proverbs 27
Do*pn not boast about tomorrow, For*ld you do not know what a day may bring forth.
Let*ln another man praise you, and not your own mouth; A*ld stranger, and not your own lips.
A*ln stone is*i heavy and sand is*i weighty, But*ld a fool’s wrath is*i heavier than both of them.
Wrath*ln is*i cruel and anger a torrent, But*ld who is*i able to stand before jealousy?
Open*ln rebuke is*i better Than*ld love carefully concealed.
Faithful*ln are*i the wounds of a friend, But*ld the kisses of an enemy are*i deceitful.
A*ln satisfied soul loathes the honeycomb, But*ld to a hungry soul every bitter thing is*i sweet.
Like*ln a bird that wanders from its nest Is*ild a man who wanders from his place.
Ointment*ln and perfume delight the heart, And*ld the sweetness of a man’s friend gives*i delight*i by hearty counsel.
Do*ln not forsake your own friend or your father’s friend, Nor*ld go to your brother’s house in the day of your calamity; Better*ld is*i a neighbor nearby than a brother far away.
My*ln son, be wise, and make my heart glad, That*ld I may answer him who reproaches me.
A*ln prudent man*i foresees evil and*i hides himself; The*ld simple pass on and*i are punished.
Take*ln the garment of him who is surety for a stranger, And*ld hold it in pledge when*i he is surety for a seductress.
He*ln who blesses his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, It*ld will be counted a curse to him.
A*ln continual dripping on a very rainy day And*ld a contentious woman are alike;
Whoever*ld restrains her restrains the wind, And*ld grasps oil with his right hand.
As*iln iron sharpens iron, So*ld a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.
Whoever*ln keeps the fig tree will eat its fruit; So*ld he who waits on his master will be honored.
As*ln in water face reflects*i face, So*ld a man’s heart reveals*i the man.
Hell*ln and Destruction are never full; So*ld the eyes of man are never satisfied.
The*ln refining pot is*i for silver and the furnace for gold, And*ld a man is*i valued*i by what others say of him.
Though*ln you grind a fool in a mortar with a pestle along with crushed grain, Yet*ild his foolishness will not depart from him.
Be*ln diligent to know the state of your flocks, And*ild attend to your herds;
For*ld riches are*i not forever, Nor*ld does a crown endure*i to all generations.
When*ild the hay is removed, and the tender grass shows itself, And*ld the herbs of the mountains are gathered in,
The*ld lambs will*i provide*i your clothing, And*ld the goats the price of a field;
You*ild shall*i have*i enough goats’ milk for your food, For*ld the food of your household, And*ld the nourishment of your maidservants.
